content.description: This is a left-to-right traverse on a slabby face that offers infinite betas. Begin with both of your hands on the southern arete, and finish with both of your hands on the NE arete.
content.location: It traverses the eastern face close to a few branches but with enough room to easily climb by. Begin on the southern arete.

content.description: Start below an out cropping in the rock, with a hand in the crack and on the arete. Move up to a ledge and make a big move left then a big move right before topping out.
content.location: It climbs the southern face that you will first walk-up on, right of the tree that is in the middle of said face.

content.description: This chill arete climb forces you to make some funky moves on some unique holds. Keep your hands and feet on the arete the entire climb after a standing start. For a V1-V1+, sit start on the southern face with your hands on the arete and your feet on the southern and eastern faces.
content.location: It ascends the Southern arete between the south and east faces and is fairly obvious as you walk up to the southern face.

content.description: The problem is to the left (west-facing) side of the boulder. The traverse starts all the way left on the arete, next to the adjacent small boulder on the ground. It begins with left hand on the arete and right hand on the angling sidepull. The problem moves up and then right, following the obvious line of crimps and edges. The problem leads to the good horn and tops out in the groove around to the right.
content.protection: A couple of pads and a spotter are nice but not essential.
content.location: Downclimb the opposite side of the boulder near the beginning of the problem.
